<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_resume_connection:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_resume_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Cannot resume connections without enabling " \
                  "MHD_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME!\n"));
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via inter-thread " \
                 "communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Cannot resume connections without enabling " \
                  "MHD_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME!\n"));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario:
The fragment as written does not itself introduce unreachable code. The if() tests a run-time value (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME) and the MHD_PANIC call is executed only when that test is true, so following code can still be reached when the test is false. Therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated by this fragment. 

However, a violation could occur in a specific situation: if MHD_PANIC is a non-returning construct (e.g. expands to abort/exit/while(1) or is annotated noreturn) and the condition is provably always true at compile time (for example daemon->options is a compile-time constant with the bit always clear or preprocessor/configuration makes the test constant), then the code after this point would be statically unreachable and would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
